name: Red Fort (Lal Qila)
description: A magnificent Mughal fortress built by Emperor Shah Jahan in the 17th century. This UNESCO World Heritage Site served as the main residence of the Mughal emperors and is a symbol of India's rich history.
audio_script: Welcome to the iconic Red Fort, the crown jewel of Mughal architecture. As you stand before these massive red sandstone walls, imagine Emperor Shah Jahan walking through these very gates. Look to your left to see the impressive Lahori Gate, the main entrance used by the Mughals. The fort stretches over 254 acres and took nearly a decade to complete. Every August 15th, India's Prime Minister hoists the national flag from these ramparts.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, early morning or late afternoon
opening_hours: Tuesday to Sunday: 9:30 AM - 4:30 PM (Closed on Mondays)
safety_warnings: Beware of fake guides offering services outside the fort
Keep valuables secure in crowded areas
Don't buy overpriced souvenirs from vendors inside
Verify official ticket counters to avoid scams
tips: Visit early morning to avoid crowds and heat
Wear comfortable walking shoes
Carry water bottle and sun protection
Don't miss the evening sound and light show
Use official ASI guides for authentic information

name: Qutub Minar
description: The world's tallest brick minaret standing at 73 meters, built in the 12th century. This UNESCO World Heritage Site represents the beginning of Muslim rule in India and showcases Indo-Islamic architecture.
audio_script: Behold the magnificent Qutub Minar, soaring 73 meters into the Delhi sky. This towering masterpiece was begun by Qutb-ud-din Aibak in 1192 and completed by his successors. Notice the intricate carvings and verses from the Quran spiraling up its red sandstone surface. Look around you at the Qutub Complex - the Iron Pillar to your right has stood rust-free for over 1,600 years, defying modern science.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, morning hours preferred
safety_warnings: Watch for pickpockets in crowded areas
Don't climb on historical structures
Avoid unauthorized guides demanding payment
Be cautious of overpriced food vendors nearby
tips: Visit during golden hour for best photography
Explore the entire Qutub Complex, not just the minaret
Read about the Iron Pillar's metallurgical mystery
Combine with nearby Mehrauli village exploration
Carry sun protection and comfortable shoes

name: India Gate
description: A majestic war memorial dedicated to 84,000 Indian soldiers who died in World War I and the Third Afghan War. This 42-meter high arch stands as a symbol of sacrifice and national pride.
audio_script: You're standing before India Gate, Delhi's most iconic landmark and a solemn tribute to our brave soldiers. This 42-meter high sandstone arch was designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens and completed in 1931. Look up to see the names of 13,300 soldiers carved into its walls. The eternal flame beneath, called Amar Jawan Jyoti, burns continuously in memory of unknown soldiers. The vast lawns around you come alive every evening with families and food vendors.
opening_hours: 24 hours (best visited during daylight or evening)
safety_warnings: Be cautious of pickpockets in evening crowds
Don't leave belongings unattended on lawns
Avoid overpriced street food vendors
Watch for traffic when crossing roads
tips: Visit during evening for the best atmosphere
Perfect spot for picnics and family time
Great for photography, especially at sunset
Try local street food but choose busy stalls
Combine with a walk down Rajpath to Rashtrapati Bhavan

name: Humayun's Tomb
description: The first garden-tomb on the Indian subcontinent and inspiration for the Taj Mahal. Built in 1570 for Mughal Emperor Humayun, this UNESCO World Heritage Site showcases Persian architectural influences.
audio_script: Welcome to Humayun's Tomb, the architectural predecessor to the famous Taj Mahal. Built by Humayun's wife Haji Begum in 1570, this magnificent structure introduced the concept of garden tombs to India. Notice the perfect symmetry as you approach - the red sandstone and white marble create a stunning contrast. Walk through the char bagh garden layout, representing paradise in Islamic tradition. The central dome you see rises 42 meters high and houses not just Humayun, but over 150 Mughal family members.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, morning or late afternoon
safety_warnings: Beware of fake guides at entrance
Don't touch or climb on monument structures
Keep valuables secure while exploring gardens
Avoid buying overpriced souvenirs from vendors
tips: Best photography during golden hour
Explore the entire garden complex, not just main tomb
Visit nearby Nizamuddin Dargah for qawwali music
Wear comfortable shoes for garden walking
Carry water and sun protection

name: Lotus Temple
description: A stunning Bahá'í House of Worship shaped like a lotus flower with 27 marble petals. Completed in 1986, it welcomes people of all faiths for meditation and prayer in complete silence.
audio_script: You're approaching the breathtaking Lotus Temple, one of Delhi's most photographed landmarks. This architectural marvel, designed by Fariborz Sahba, consists of 27 marble petals arranged in clusters of three to form a lotus flower. As you enter, notice the complete silence maintained inside - no talking, no photography, just peaceful meditation. The temple welcomes people of all religions and backgrounds. The nine pools surrounding the structure represent the lotus floating on water, creating a serene atmosphere perfect for reflection.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, avoid Monday closures
opening_hours: Tuesday to Sunday: 9:00 AM - 5:30 PM (Closed Mondays)
safety_warnings: Remove shoes before entering temple premises
Maintain complete silence inside the temple
No photography allowed inside the main hall
Be cautious of overcharging by auto drivers
tips: Visit during weekdays to avoid crowds
Maintain silence and respect inside
Beautiful for photography from outside
Combine with nearby Kalkaji Temple visit
Wear modest clothing and be prepared to remove shoes

name: Jama Masjid
description: India's largest mosque built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan between 1650-1656. This magnificent structure can accommodate 25,000 worshippers and offers stunning views of Old Delhi from its minarets.
audio_script: Welcome to Jama Masjid, India's largest and most magnificent mosque. Built by Emperor Shah Jahan, the same ruler who created the Taj Mahal, this architectural masterpiece took six years to complete. As you enter through one of the three gateways, notice the vast courtyard that can hold 25,000 people. The red sandstone and white marble create a striking contrast against the Delhi sky. If you're feeling adventurous, climb the southern minaret for breathtaking views of Old Delhi's bustling streets below.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, avoid Friday prayer times
safety_warnings: Dress modestly - cover arms, legs, and head
Remove shoes before entering mosque premises
Avoid visiting during prayer times
Be respectful of worshippers and customs
tips: Dress conservatively and carry head covering

Climb minaret for panoramic Old Delhi views

name: Akshardham Temple
description: A modern architectural marvel showcasing traditional Indian culture and spirituality. Opened in 2005, this massive temple complex features intricate carvings, exhibitions, and cultural shows celebrating India's heritage.
audio_script: You're standing before Akshardham, a modern wonder that celebrates 10,000 years of Indian culture. This magnificent temple, built without steel and completed in just five years, showcases the finest Indian craftsmanship. Notice the intricate carvings on pink sandstone and white marble - over 20,000 sculptures and statues adorn this complex. Inside, you'll find exhibitions, an IMAX theater, and musical fountains. The central monument houses a 11-foot gold-leafed statue of Bhagwan Swaminarayan, surrounded by 148 elephants carved from single stones.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, Tuesday to Sunday
opening_hours: Tuesday to Sunday: 9:30 AM - 6:30 PM (Closed Mondays)
safety_warnings: No mobile phones, cameras, or electronic items allowed
Deposit belongings at security counter before entry
Follow dress code - no shorts, sleeveless tops
Be prepared for thorough security checks
tips: Allow full day for complete experience
No electronic items allowed - deposit at entrance

Wear modest clothing and comfortable shoes
Try the vegetarian food court inside

name: Lodhi Garden
description: A beautiful 90-acre landscaped garden containing 15th-century tombs of Sayyid and Lodhi dynasties. This peaceful green space offers a perfect blend of history, nature, and recreation in the heart of Delhi.
audio_script: Welcome to Lodhi Garden, Delhi's most beautiful historical park where nature and heritage blend seamlessly. As you walk through these 90 acres, you're surrounded by 500-year-old tombs of the Sayyid and Lodhi rulers. Look to your right to see the magnificent Bara Gumbad, and ahead lies the tomb of Mohammed Shah. The garden was redesigned by Lady Willingdon in 1936, creating this perfect harmony of Mughal architecture and English landscaping. Early morning joggers and yoga enthusiasts make this a living, breathing space.
best_time_to_visit: October to March, early morning or evening
safety_warnings: Avoid isolated areas during early morning or late evening
Keep belongings secure while exercising
Be cautious of stray dogs in some areas
Don't venture into restricted archaeological zones
tips: Perfect for morning walks and jogging
Great spot for photography and picnics
Explore all the historical tombs within
Visit during flower blooming season (winter)
